title: How to Add Movies to Apple TV

steps.title: Click on the Apple iTunes Movies link provided to you in the Sources section of this article.
steps.content: Click on the Apple iTunes Movies link provided to you in the Sources section of this article.

steps.title: Browse the list of available movies displayed on the landing page.
steps.content: Browse the list of available movies displayed on the landing page. If the movie you want to purchase and download to iTunes is not displayed, you can search for the movie of your choice using the search box located in the upper-right corner.

steps.title: Click on the link for the movie you want downloaded to iTunes.
steps.content: Click on the link for the movie you want downloaded to iTunes. A preview screen will then load, providing you with more details about that particular movie.

steps.title: Click on the button labeled "View in iTunes" next to the movie description.
steps.content: Click on the button labeled "View in iTunes" next to the movie description. Your Internet browser will display a prompt informing you that the iTunes application will open on your computer. After opening, iTunes will then display the purchase options for the movie you have chosen.

steps.title: Select the desired payment option for the movie from within the iTunes application.
steps.content: Select the desired payment option for the movie from within the iTunes application. Most movies will provide you with the option to purchase, or rent the movie.

steps.title: Enter your Apple ID and password into the designated fields to sign into the iTunes store and complete your purchase.
steps.content: Enter your Apple ID and password into the designated fields to sign into the iTunes store and complete your purchase. The movie you have chosen will be downloaded directly into your iTunes, and is now available for you to sync and use with Apple TV.

steps.title: Navigate to the movie you want imported to iTunes for use with Apple TV from its storage location on your computer.
steps.content: Navigate to the movie you want imported to iTunes for use with Apple TV from its storage location on your computer.

steps.title: Verify that the format of your movie is compatible for use with Apple TV.
steps.content: Verify that the format of your movie is compatible for use with Apple TV. Video files in formats of .m4v, .mp4, and .mov are compatible with Apple TV; however, videos with the formats of .avi and .wmv will not work with Apple TV. Go to the Apple Support link ending with "HT1532#" in the Sources section of this article to access a complete list of video formats that will, and will not work with Apple TV.

steps.title: Open the iTunes application on your computer.
steps.content: Open the iTunes application on your computer.

steps.title: Click and drag your movie file from its storage location, then drop the file into iTunes.
steps.content: Click and drag your movie file from its storage location, then drop the file into iTunes. You can now access the movie from the "Movies" folder of your iTunes library, and sync it with Apple TV.

steps.title: Launch your iMovie application, then navigate to the movie you want added to Apple TV.
steps.content: Launch your iMovie application, then navigate to the movie you want added to Apple TV.

steps.title: Click on the button labeled "Share," then select "QuickTime."
steps.content: Click on the button labeled "Share," then select "QuickTime."

steps.title: Select the option to compress your movie, then choose "Expert Settings" from the pop-up menu that displays.
steps.content: Select the option to compress your movie, then choose "Expert Settings" from the pop-up menu that displays.

steps.title: Click the "Share" button again, then enter your file preferences.
steps.content: Click the "Share" button again, then enter your file preferences. You will have the option to enter a name for the file, and select a file destination.

steps.title: Select "Movie to Apple TV" from within the export drop-down menu, then click "Save."
steps.content: Select "Movie to Apple TV" from within the export drop-down menu, then click "Save." Your iMovie will then be saved in a format compatible with Apple TV.

steps.title: Open the Apple iTunes application on your computer.
steps.content: Open the Apple iTunes application on your computer.

steps.title: Navigate to the iMovie file you recently saved, then click and drag the file into your Apple iTunes.
steps.content: Navigate to the iMovie file you recently saved, then click and drag the file into your Apple iTunes. You can now sync the movie with Apple TV within iTunes.

steps.title: Know the types of video files supported by AppleTV.
steps.content: Know the types of video files supported by AppleTV. Though AppleTV is a great way to view most movies, it's not a great way to view all movies. Certain video file extensions are incompatible with AppleTV and, thus, can't be played within the program. Knowing which files will and won't work in AppleTV ahead of time can be a big time-saver: Generally, mp4, m4v and mov can be easily transferred. Conversely, mkv, wmv, webm, and avi are usually difficult to transfer or incompatible entirely.

steps.title: Use a free converter application to convert to mp4.
steps.content: Use a free converter application to convert to mp4. Mp4 files are easy for AppleTV to play, so, if you can convert your incompatible file from its original file type to mp4, you should be able to play it. Luckily, several converter apps are available for free online - simply Google, download, and install the software, then convert your file to mp4 (or another supported format). Some converters will even have a special Apple TV profile pre-programmed for easy conversion. Below are just a few popular video converters available for download: MPEG Streamclip Handbrake Format Factory (Windows only) Freemake Video Converter (Windows only)

steps.title: Import your new mp4 files into iTunes as normal.
steps.content: Import your new mp4 files into iTunes as normal. With luck, your new files should work just fine.

steps.title: If necessary, adjust the parameters of problematic files.
steps.content: If necessary, adjust the parameters of problematic files. In some rare cases, it's difficult to get files to play in AppleTV even after converting them to a compatible format like mp4. In some cases, you may also need to adjust the parameters of the video file to make it easier to play. Here are compatible settings for several AppleTV-supported file types.: H.264 video up to 1080p, 30 frames per second, High or Main Profile level 4.0 or lower, Baseline profile level 3.0 or lower with AAC-LC audio up to 160 Kbps per channel, 48kHz, stereo audio in .m4v, .mp4 and .mov file formats MPEG-4 video up to 2.5 Mbps, 640 by 480 pixels, 30 frames per second, Simple Profile with AAC-LC audio up to 160 Kbps, 48kHz, stereo audio in .m4v, .mp4 and .mov file formats Motion JPEG (M-JPEG) up to 35 Mbps, 1280 by 720 pixels, 30 frames per second, audio in ulaw, PCM stereo audio in .avi file format
